definition: to do more than is required (idiom); superfluous/gilding the lily
many/much/often/a lot of/numerous/more/in excess/how (to what extent)/multi-/Taiwan pr. [duo2] when it means "how"
this/these
one/1/single/a (article)/as soon as/entire/whole/all/throughout/"one" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 1)/also pr. [yao1] for greater clarity when spelling out numbers digit by digit
to lift/to hold up/to cite/to enumerate/to act/to raise/to choose/to elect/act/move/deed
variant of 舉|举[ju3]

sentences.english: But concerns over intellectual property rights have proved to be unfounded.
sentences.chinese: 对于知识产权问题存在顾虑显然多此一举。

sentences.english: To talk about the beautiful sunset is to gild the lily.
sentences.chinese: 谈论日落之美是多此一举。

sentences.english: Comment on this would be to gild the lily.
sentences.chinese: 这一评论就是多此一举。

sentences.english: These regulations become largely redundant in an era of carbon taxes.
sentences.chinese: 这些规定在碳税时代，很大程度上是多此一举的。
运煤到纽卡索，多此一举。

definition: lit. draw legs on a snake (idiom); fig. to ruin the effect by adding sth superfluous/to overdo it
to take great pains/to go to a lot of trouble
lit. to take off trousers to fart/fig. to do something absolutely unnecessary/fig. to make things too complicated
to ask for trouble/to invite difficulties
to muster large forces/to get a great number of people involved (in carrying out some task)
to make a big fuss over a minor issue (idiom)
there is no need/why should
to ask for trouble (idiom)/to make a rod for one's own back
variant of 小題大做|小题大做[xiao3 ti2 da4 zuo4]
to go to war (idiom)/to make a big fuss over sth
need not/unnecessary
to force someone to do something
to ask a question, already knowing the answer
to bring trouble on oneself
trying to hide it makes it more conspicuous (idiom); A cover up only makes matters worse.
to follow the path to one's own doom (idiom)/to bring about one's own destruction
